item.title: Switch to the GW perspective
item.description:
In the Package Explorer, double click the graph you've created earlier, so that the editor is displayed.
Switch to the GW4E perspective
Click the Properties view
You will now manipulate graph elements. Whenever you've done some update , save your work, by clicking the Save menu toolbar button.

item.title: Play with graph elements, menu and toolbar
item.description:
- 1- In the palette click the Vertex element
- 2- Click the Vertex element in the palette, move the cursor on top of the graph and click, a new Vertex with a default name is displayed
- 3- Modify the name as you want
- 4- Click Edge in the palette, then click the Start Vertex, drag your cursor until you are over any vertex, and click it
As you can see a no link is created, because the model accepts only one edge and we already have one. - 5- Delete the e_init edge and repeat the operation.
- 6- Click the newly created edge
- 7- Click the red cross icon in the menu toolbar, the edge is deleted
- 8- Click the undo yellow icon, the edge is back
- 9- Click the newly created Vertex
-10- Click the red cross icon in the menu toolbar, the Vertex and the edge are deleted
-11- Click the undo yellow icon, the vertex and the edge are back
-12- Click the created Vertex
-13- Click the Copy icon and then click the graph, the Paste icon is enabled
-14- Click the Paste icon, the Vertex is duplicated
-15- Right-click the graph, a popup menu appears with the Undo, Redo and Delete menu items we already used just above
-16- Right-click the graph, and click Show In Package Explorer, the graph file is revealed in the Package Explorer
-17- Right-click the graph, and click Layout. You can see many Layout menu options. Depending on the graph the result might be what you're looking for .. or not . This is an experimental feature.

item.title: Filtering graph elements
item.description:
Whenever the graph is huge and cannot be displayed in one shot on the screen, it might be difficult to focus on particular element. In this case, you can use the filters. In the Outline view, check the Filter check box. When elements are filtered, you can click on them to put the focus on the desired element.
To begin enable Filtering by checking the Filter check box.
Filtering by Name
Enter a value on the name text field, the elements in the outline view table are filtered depending on the entered value.
Filtering by Description
Enter a value on the description text field, the elements in the outline view table are filtered depending on the entered value.
Filtering by Blocked status
Select Yes when you want to display Blocked element.
Select No when you want to display non blocked element.
Select Empty when you don't want to take into account this filter.
Filtering on Vertex properties
Expand the Vertex Filters section
Filtering by Requirement
Enter a value on the Req text field, the elements in the outline view table are filtered depending on the entered value.
Filtering by Shared status
Select Yes when you want to display Shared vertex
Select No when you want to display simple Vertex
Select Empty when you don't want to take into account this filter.
Filtering by Init value
Enter a value on the Init text field, the elements in the outline view table are filtered depending on the entered value.
Filtering on Edge properties
Expand the Edge Filters section
Filtering by Weight
Select an operator sign (upper,lower,equal,...) and enter a value, the elements in the outline view table are filtered depending on the entered value.
Filtering by Guard status
Select Yes when you want to display Guarded edge
Select No when you want to display no Guarded edge
Select Empty when you don't want to take into account this filter.
Filtering by Action status
Select Yes when you want to display edge having script in the Action
Select No when you want to display edges that dont have script in the Action
Select Empty when you don't want to take into account this filter.
